titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Rockefeller University Press, Subject Files FA917

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-07-28 00:06:03 -0400.

revisiondesc.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvists’ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Rockefeller University Press, Subject Files

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In order to assist in the dissemination of scientific investigations conducted at the Institute and elsewhere, publication was an early and important activity of The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. A senior member of the scientific staff was usually the editor of a periodical. As early as 1910 the Institute had a Publication Service, which was supervised from 1910 by Editha C. Campbell until she retired in the fall of 1940. A Department of Illustration and Photography was under a part-time arrangement with De. Eduard Learning from 1906 until 1910 when Louis Schmidt undertook the direction of a full-time department. Louis Schmidt was at the head of the department until he reached the age of 70 in 1936. The work in the Department of Illustrations included hand-drawn illustrations for publications, photographs, moving pictures of experimental procedures made for the various investigators and used for a variety of purposes. Louis Schmidt served on a consultant basis until his death in 1939. Joseph Blauvelt Haulenbeek was acting in charge of Illustrations during that time and named officially in charge of illustrations in 1942, serving until he resigned September 1, 1946. Julian Alexander Carlile who was in charge of illustrations in the Department of Animal and Plant Pathology at Princeton took charge of the New York Department starting October 1, 1947 and divided his time between the two departments until they were consolidated during 1950. He directed the expanding department until his death in 1959 when he was succeeded by Richard F. Carter until 1964. In the academic year 1968/1969 Lewis William Koster became Manager of Graphic Services until 1973. March 1973 Bill Leyrer was appointed to that position.
Florence M. Stewart succeeded Editha Campbell in charge of the Publication Service in 1940 and served until she retired June 30, 1963, when she was succeeded by Margaret E. Broadbent.

Effective January 1, 1957 Charles Irvin Campbell was appointed Administrative Associate for Information Services. He had responsibility for a variety of information services among which were Secretary of the Library Committee, Librarian, ex officio, and supervision of the Publication Service and Illustration and Duplicating Services. Included were publication duties of such items as the Annual Report, Rockefeller Institute Quarterly, and the Calendar of Events. On October 20, 1958 the Board of Trustees approved a cooperative arrangement with the Oxford University Press to assist in producing, advertising and selling publications of the newly established Rockefeller Institute Press. The plan was for the Institute to continue publishing journals in accord with previously established policy and arrangements. Charles I. Campbell was appointed Director of The Rockefeller Institute Press. The Publications Service became the Journals Department without change of personnel or function. A new Books and Reports Department was created with responsibility for the production of books and the publication of bulletins and reports issued by the Institute.

January 1, 1960 Reynard F. Biemiller was appointed Assistant Director of The Rockefeller Institute Press. Effective December 5, 1960 Raymond B. Griffiths was appointed to the newly created position of Executive Editor of the Journal of Cell Biology.
Charles I. Campbell resigned May 15, 1962 and Joseph G. Sutton served as Acting Director of the Press from January 1963 until in 1964 William Arthur Bayless was named Director of the Press.
William Bayless retired as Director of The Rockefeller University Press on February 8, 1980. As of February 11, 1980, Mrs. Helene Jordan agreed to serve as acting director of the Press.
Effective July 1, 1980, Mrs. Helene Jordan was appointed Director of The Rockefeller University Press.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

fileplan.head: File Plan note
fileplan.p: Former Classification: I 500 and I 501 (Boxes 1-3); I 501-U (Box 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: subject files.

did.unittitle: Christmas Lectures

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1958 Dr. Mirsky presented the idea of holding lectures on science for high school students at the period during the Christmas holidays (based on the pattern of the Christmas Lectures at the Royal Institution in London). The first lecturer was René Dubos who spoke on "The Unseen World" which subsequently appeared as a book from The Rockefeller Institute Press.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For additional Christmas lecture material see the Alfred E. Mirsky Papers and the Christmas lecture file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this file deals primarily with correspondence and arrangements made to collect various films that were used for the lectures, the previews and opinions of the various films viewed, until the final decisions were made.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in three folders and one envelope.

did.unittitle: William A. Bayless
Rous, Peyton. 6 letters to William Bayless

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes (4 holograph) reprint from NATURE 207 (1965) "Viruses and tumor causation" and two obituary articles by J.S. Henderson: American Philosophical yearbook, 1971 (2 copies) and ARCHIVES OF PATHOLOGY 90 (1970).

did.unittitle: William A. Bayless - Biographical material and photographs
Subject Files

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1964 William Bayless was named Director of the Rockefeller University Press.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Date received or inventoried: 1978 and later

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: From 1978 and later discreet subject files were sent to the Archives.

did.unittitle: Dolce, Philip C., editor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Between 1974 and 1975 there was consideration of a University Press publication called SCIENCE AND SOCIETY: A HUMANISTIC VIEW. This was to consist of selected portions from a CBS/TV series planned with the sponsorship of Bergen Community College with Philip C. Dolce as coordinator. The book was not published but the file consists of plans, programs with numerous revisions, grant proposal and correspondence.

did.unittitle: Goudsmit, Samuel A

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence which also includes comments on the film "The Making of the Atom Bomb" transcript and edited versions of talk at the Seminar on Quantum Mechanics at American Institute of Physics on 6 October 1964; draft of article "The Physics Editor" [Correspondence re[? ] hieroglyph book].

did.unittitle: Opie, Eugene L. - Chinese Medicine manuscript (photocopy) see also Bronk papers Rockefeller University subject file under "Opie"
Opie, Eugene L.- Correspondence about publication by the Rockefeller University Press of Dr. Opie's "Traditional Chinese Medicine"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes calculations of costs, comments regarding suitability for RU Press. Also includes photocopy of Opie article on founding of The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research prepared for George W. Corner.

did.unittitle: Seitz, Frederick

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Primarily copies of correspondence and informational memoranda between William Bayless and Frederick Seitz dealing with publications, stationary and matters of production, Christmas Party invitations.
Items of special interest are listed below.

did.unittitle: Changes in faculty titles for fiscal year 1971
Copy of Commencement address at Cornell Medical College "Science in Public Crisis"
"Parable of the Far-sighted Scientist"
Charles Campbell; William Bayless
Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Seal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Casting of original seal. Box bears stamp: Made by Florentine Mastercraft Studio 132 East 26th St. N.Y.C.

did.unittitle: Correspondence between Charles Campbell and Rudolph Ruzicka

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Including a few letters from Douglas Whitaker, George Corner, Dr. William Robbins, Dr. Eugene L. Opie, Detlev Bronk and Robert Loeb dealing with designs submitted for new University seal and considerations for final decision. Included in the correspondence is a summary from the Minutes of meetings of the Board of Scientific Directors referring to the original seal and an explanation of the original design symbols.
